title: Fix data corruption during compression of large chunks

labels.name: 🪳 bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body:
There are 3 problems involved:
1. `ArrowMsg::uncompressed_size` is defined as an `int32`. That issue speaks for itself.
2. The encoding path tracks payload sizes using `usize`, and then silently cast them to `int32` when encoding the Protobuf data, leading to gibberish and crashes during decoding.
3. `lz4_flex` has similar casting bugs: it can encode 64bit values but cannot decode them. Once again the `as` keyword is involved.

This PR fixes 1 and 2. All the changes are backward and forward compatible because:
* In protobuf, `uint64` is a strict superset of `int32`: both are unsigned varints on the wire.
* There exist no valid RRD files out there with negative values for `uncompressed_size`.

We can already log much bigger chunks than before, but not too big, otherwise `lz4` itself will during decoding:
```
thread 'decompress' panicked at 'attempt to add with overflow'
lz4_flex-0.11.5/src/block/decompress_safe.rs:39
stack backtrace:
   6: core::panicking::panic_fmt
             at core/src/panicking.rs:75:14
   7: core::panicking::panic_const::panic_const_add_overflow
             at core/src/panicking.rs:175:17
   8: std::sys::backtrace::__rust_begin_short_backtrace
   9: core::ops::function::FnOnce::call_once{{vtable.shim}}
  10: <alloc::boxed::Box<F,A> as core::ops::function::FnOnce<Args>>::call_once
             at alloc/src/boxed.rs:1966:9
      <alloc::boxed::Box<F,A> as core::ops::function::FnOnce<Args>>::call_once
             at alloc/src/boxed.rs:1966:9
      std::sys::pal::unix::thread::Thread::new::thread_start
             at std/src/sys/pal/unix/thread.rs:97:17
  11: <unknown>
  12: <unknown>
```

I'll have a follow-up PR for the `lz4_flex` issue.

---

* Half of fixing https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/11516
  * The other half requires patching `lz4_flex` (on it)

---

Checks:
* [x] `rerun` with `--nb_scans 2000`
* [x] `rerun rrd stats` with `--nb_scans 2000`
* [x] :no_entry: `rerun` with `--nb_scans 3000` -> bug in lz4
* [x] :no_entry: `rerun rrd stats` with `--nb_scans 3000` -> bug in lz4
* [x] All dataplatform test suites pass
* [x] Can load old RRDs no problem

title: Flatten connection_client error hierarchy

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: dataplatform
labels.description: Rerun Data Platform integration

body:
### Related

- Part of RR-2395

### Why
When it comes to exposing errors to client (and specifically thinking at the Python SDK) we want:
- To have meaningful error messages that humans (primarily users and secondarily developers) can understand
- To have actionable types that computers can use to react to errors

Our previous taxonomy of errors in the client was very deeply nested and made it hard to classify the errors
in a way that was machine friendly, i.e., it was hiding very deep the underlying source of the error, and mainly
highlighting the operation where the error happened.

### What

This is an attempt to flatten that taxonomy. All errors generated by the connection client will be of type `ApiError` and 
will have a `ApiErrorKind` of one of few types. The assumption is that those  types are generic across all operations,
and are machine actionable.

`ApiError` is expected to include a human understandable error message string as well as wrapping the underlying `source`
of the error, for further inspection.

### Next
In my ideal mental world, `ExternalError` in `rerun_py` should follow a similar model (or even disappear completely in favor of a more global `ApiError`-equivalent). This will allow to have all the possible error in just a bunch of useful classes instead of this odd mixed taxonomy.

I did not do it in this PR because I would have had too touch way more things I am willing to at this stage.

title: Implement shallow RRD pattern definition for ImHex

labels.name: 🧑‍💻 dev experience
labels.description: developer experience (excluding CI)

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body: This is an incomplete Pattern Language definition for the [ImHex](https://imhex.werwolv.net/) editor. It came to life over the week-end as I was having night terrors of RRD corruption, and had been looking for an excuse to learn ImHex for a while. To use it, load any RRD file in the ImHex editor, and import this file as a pattern definition. Unfortunately this merely covers the very outer layers of the Rerun RRD file encoding. The RRD protocol relies on several layers of encodings that require code generation as well as third party libraries. To provide a proper pattern definition for the RRD protocol, not only a full Rerun ImHex plugin would be required (and that's C++), but the existing codebase would also need custom Arrow and Protobuf decoders to map byte spans to actual column names, etc. Still, it's a start. May it serves as breadcrumbs for the next soul venturing into this. Here's an example of a `dna.rrd`:

body:
### Related

* part of https://linear.app/rerun/project/demo-ready-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines-d0a110693312/
* part of https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2532/pr-tracking-demo-read-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines

* closes https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2322/mock-task-related-endpoints
* sibling https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/1847

### What

This PR moves and adapt a couple of test covering part of registration, partition table and dataset manifest schema and data, and tasks.

It also updates the OSS server as follows:
- The task-related endpoints are mocked.
- The in-memory store use compaction as per env variable (finally not needed for this PR, but I figured I'd leave it anyways)

Notes:
- The dataset manifest is currently disabled if the endpoint is unimplemented, because that's the case in OSS. They will soon be though, and the test will be re-enabled then.
- I made the `size_bytes` field of the manifest implementation-defined (aka it's not covered in snapshots). OSS uses heap size while Cloud uses, I believe, size on disk, and they don't match.

title: Scaffolding for a shareable, reference test suite for redap

labels.name: 🔨 testing
labels.description: testing and benchmarks

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related

* part of https://linear.app/rerun/project/demo-ready-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines-d0a110693312/
* part of https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2532/pr-tracking-demo-read-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines
* sibling https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/1844

### What

There is no point bringing the OSS server to parity if that parity is neither verified, nor enforced. This PR introduces the scaffolding for a reference Rerun Data Protocol (redap) test suite.

Quoting its README.md:

> This test suite is specifically focused on the redap layer.  In particular it aims to cover what our API's `*.proto` files leave implicit. This includes at least:
> - all the dataframes (schema, content)
> - all the stateful behaviors (e.g. chunk keys, tasks, etc.)
> 
> As such, it is implemented to be as close as possible to the actual API boundary, aka the (incorrectly named) `RerunCloudService` trait.
> 
> ### Goals
> 
> - Cover all aspects of the redap layer, including dataframe schemas and stateful behaviors.
> - Serve as the definitive reference of what redap is.
> - Ensure conformance of all implementations (including, possibly, third-party).
> 
> ### Non-goals
> 
> - Test layers outside the redap boundary, including `re_redap_client::ConnectionClient` or the Python SDK.
> - Test anything about the internals of the redap implementors (OSS server, Rerun Cloud, etc.)

Currently, this test suite contains a single test as proof-of-concept. I've picked one that I thought would pass with both implementations. Of course, it didn't, so this PR also fixes the OSS server so that test passes.

Notes:
- All the code in `util` has been copied straight from the `dataplatform`.
- The crate is marked as `publish = true`. Primarily because CI told me to, but it also kind of make sense given that this crates serves as reference on redap.

title: Introduce all-in-one `StreamDecoder` iterator and use it _everywhere_

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: CLI
labels.description: Related to the Rerun CLI

body:
This PRs augments the existing `StreamDecoder` with the couple features that it was still missing, and introduce a new `StreamDecoderIterator` that builds on top of it to provide an all-in-one fully-featured decoder that supports all use cases.

All in all, this new all-in-one decoder supports (in no particular order):
* Native and web, both with or without control of the underlying IO loop
* Tail mode, using end-of-stream markers (when coupled with a `RetryableFileReader`)
* Support for concatenated file streams, with and without EOS markers (!)
* Protection against under and over IO buffering by requiring `BufRead` instead of `Read`
* Capable of generically switching between transport and application level decoding
* Generic support for all the weird things: version propagation, app ID patching, etc
* Eager initialization for early error detection

Whether we should or shouldn't support all these features in the first place is a topic for another day (specifically: when we start looking into RRD footers).
For now, the point is each of these features are required by one or more entrypoints in the existing OSS codebase, and therefore the goal for now is to reach parity so have one decoder to rule them all.

The focus here is purely on OSS: for now, the dataplatform decoder (`StreamingDecoder`) is still completely independent. I'm hoping I can apply the same kind of reconciliation on that end in a second pass.

--- 

This PR is part of an upcoming series of PRs to pay off organic growth debt in our encoding/decoding stack.

* DNM: requires #11455
* Closes #11266

---

* [x] `@rerun-bot full-check`
* [x] `cat ./tests/assets/rrd/examples/* | pixi run rerun rrd merge | pixi run rerun -`
* [x] `cat ./tests/assets/rrd/examples/* | pixi run rerun rrd route --application-id my_app --recording-id my_rec | pixi run rerun -`

title: Do not include metadata when rendering table in html

labels.name: 🪳 bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: 🧑‍💻 dev experience
labels.description: developer experience (excluding CI)

labels.name: notebook

title: `StreamDecoder`: fix support for out-of-order legacy store ID

labels.name: sdk-rust
labels.description: Rust logging API

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body:
This PR ports the test suite from the legacy `Decoder` to the new `StreamDecoder`, to ensure they are fully compatible.

In doing so, I stumbled upon a bug where the `StreamDecoder` would enter an obscure irrecoverable state when faced with an out-of-order legacy store ID (i.e. a store ID missing an app ID).
This PR fixes that.

Also removed some duplicated code on the way.

---

This PR is part of an upcoming series of PRs to pay off organic growth debt in our encoding/decoding stack.

* DNM: requires #11452

title: Convert remaining deps into workspace deps

labels.name: 🧑‍💻 dev experience
labels.description: developer experience (excluding CI)

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: concerning crates, pip packages etc

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
Done using https://crates.io/crates/cargo-autoinherit

This reverts our previous policy of keeping examples exempt from workspace deps.

The previous policy was based on the idea that it should be easy to copy-and-paste an example, but we never really adhered to that anyway since they all have `rerun = { path = "../../../crates/top/rerun" }` in them.
 
My thinking now is that it's more important to make it easy for us developers to keep our dependency tree nice and updated. In particular, I want to run `cargo upgrade` (from https://crates.io/crates/cargo-edit) and not have dozens of files change

title: `StreamDecoder`: lift naming confusion regarding chunks

labels.name: sdk-rust
labels.description: Rust logging API

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body:
This is just a pure renaming pass.

`StreamDecoder`'s job is to deal with chunks of bytes, and it used to call those `chunks`. This was extremely confusing to me when trying to understand the code, since _chunk_ is such an overloaded term for us.
This PR just makes it as clear as possible that this is about _byte chunks_, not _Rerun chunks_.

---

This PR is part of an upcoming series of PRs to pay off organic growth debt in our encoding/decoding stack.

* DNM: requires #11450

title: Encoder: simplified APIs and improved discoverability

labels.name: sdk-rust
labels.description: Rust logging API

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body:
The Encoder was offloading so much complexity to end-users of the API by forcing them to somehow discover, pick and figure out how to use a bunch of complicated freestanding helpers such as `encode_ref_as_bytes_local`.

All these freestanding functions have now been replaced by a couple of simpler, more generic, more discoverable helper methods.

---

This PR is part of an upcoming series of PRs to pay off organic growth debt in our encoding/decoding stack.

* DNM: requires #11446

title: Merge `DroppableEncoder` and `Encoder` into a single facility

labels.name: sdk-rust
labels.description: Rust logging API

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body:
Our RRD encoding facilities are currently implemented by two distinct types: `DroppableEncoder` & `Encoder`.

This makes understanding how to use the API unnecessarily painful. Turns out the only reason things are done this way is because of an implementation detail related to the `Drop` implementation.
Instead of passing off that complexity to end-users of the API, we now contain it to the implementation instead.

In addition to that, the `AlreadyFinished` logic was broken, so fix too while we're at it.

---

This PR is part of an upcoming series of PRs to pay off organic growth debt in our encoding/decoding stack.

title: Improve many-entity performance by fixing redundant `AnnotationContext` lookups (also affects scene without annotation contexts)

labels.name: 📉 performance
labels.description: Optimization, memory use, etc

body: ### Related * small part of https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/8233 ### What "Rea", non-changelog title: "static execution phase for ViewContextSystem & store subscriber for marking up AnnotationContext" For upcoming transform processing I wanted to have a way to execute something _once_ per frame _if_ a context system exists. I tried to make this as low-tech as possible and after a few iteration I came up with `ViewContextSystem::execute_static` which goes a bit out of its way to _not_ introduce a new type of view system. I then figured I could use this to eliminate the extremly wasteful `AnnotationContext` lookups which can amount to a lot of wasted perf. Turns out doing a minimal store subscriber there is the _real_ win, but I made use of `execute_static` regardless for passing on the determined annotations. Using script from https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/11437: ``` pixi run rerun-release --threads=1 pixi run -e py python tests/python/many_entities/main.py ``` Before: After: -> Annotation context no longer shows up as it should (saving us 15ms here without much effort) (resolving non-existant overrides is still horrifying ;-)) Annotations on the "horse example" work still fine: **Review commit by commit recommended (of which there are two ;-))**

title: Add Minimal Notebook Validation

labels.name: 🔨 testing
labels.description: testing and benchmarks

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related
https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/11416
I requested the notebooks get moved so our automated examples test would make sure the notebooks aren't broken. Unfortunately we don't test any of our notebooks so most were broken. 

A little bit related to broader notebook testing improvement https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-1880/test-our-jupyter-notebooks-on-ci

### What
I highly recommend reviewing with rich diff for notebooks enabled.
* Adds nbqa so we can run mypy on the notebooks to at least ensure the apis align
   * I couldn't get the config working so unfortunately I just have the directories to search listed in the pixi command
* Adds nbstripout but doesn't yet tie it to our py-fmt. Jupyter notebook outputs are just binary so that will bloat the repo and complicate diffs. Unfortunately nbstripout doesn't have a nice config setup so I just put together a simple wrapper.
* I made two actual code changes not just in tests since it made sense to resolve notebook mypy errors
   1. I made component_type a class method. We basically have component type raw strings everywhere probably because it wasn't easy before to grab them from the class definition rather than instance
   2. If we have a recording string the api should actually be a little different than asking globally. I assume we'll always find the id so we universally return a string.
   
This still doesn't execute our notebooks which is probably a worthwhile followup issue.

title: Determine per-view overrides in parallel (-> faster many entities + many views on native)

labels.name: 📺 re_viewer
labels.description: affects re_viewer itself

labels.name: 📉 performance
labels.description: Optimization, memory use, etc

body: ### Related * part of https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/8233 ### Description Override determiniation (even if there are no overrides at all) can get **very** slow for many entities. This PR doesn't address that, but makes it parallel per-view. This alleviates the pain a little bit and was fairly straight forward to do. Came up because I couldn't bear the sight in * https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/11437 Makes it ~neatly~ stacked if multithreading isn't opted out or you're running on the web (this happens to be the slowest part in this synthetic scene which consists entirely of transforms, created via upcoming `pixi run -e py python tests/python/many_entity_transforms/main.py --transforms-only`)

title: Transform resolution is no longer a store subscriber

labels.name: 🚜 refactor
labels.description: Change the code, not the functionality

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### Related

* Fixes RR-2489

### What

Mostly a pure refactor. May change perf characteristics a bit, most notably no more transform processing occurs at all until a 3D view is created. Not expecting any major shifts though.

`TransformCacheStoreSubscriber` -> `TransformResolutionCache`

In a nutshell, this removes the tight coupling of transform logic with store subscribers and migrates keeping transforms up to date in the Viewer to a Viewer-Cache.
Chunk events are still used in `TransformResolutionCache` but are a merely a thin aspect of its frontend and can be bypassed for chunk-adding only.

Motivation:
* major step towards coalescing into a multi-faceted `TransformDatabase` object which internally will contain transform resolution cache as well as transform tree
    * `TransformCacheStoreSubscriber` being a subscriber dependency made this unwiedly as we couldn't keep all objects in the same place easily due to the static nature of store subscribers
* tightly control when what is updated and how parallel that happens
* allow transform resolution with partial knowledge - we want to feed in chunks manually and observe the results for the given set of chunks
    * this is important for a query aware future where we can't rely on chugging through fully downloaded stores 


Testing:
Seems to be covered well enough by unit tests on `TransformResolutionCache` as well as integration tests in `re_view_spatial` (both of which prevented mistakes here!)


Reviewing:
Lots of whitespace in existing tests due to nesting decrease (!) as things are no longer happening under a subscriber lock

title: Introduce the dataset manifest and remove layer information from the partition table

labels.name: sdk-python
labels.description: Python logging API

labels.name: dataplatform
labels.description: Rerun Data Platform integration

body:
### Related

* part of https://linear.app/rerun/project/demo-ready-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines-d0a110693312/
* part of https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2532/pr-tracking-demo-read-oss-server-for-data-transformation-pipelines
* part of https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2476/remove-layer-specific-columns-from-the-partition-table-and-introduce-a
* sibling of https://github.com/rerun-io/dataplatform/pull/1826

### What

Introduces gRPC endpoints and associated SDK method to access the dataset manifest table, which contains a row per layer. Also, remove most layer-related columns from the partition table.

This PR also attempts to solidify the notion that `Scan{PartitionTable|DatasetManifest}Response` is the One True Source(tm) of information on the returned dataframe's schema.

Future work:
- implement dataset manifest endpoint in the OSS server: RR-2482
- implement dataset manifest in the catalog provider: https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/issues/11444

TODO

title: Update wgpu to 27

labels.name: 🔺 re_renderer
labels.description: rendering, graphics, GPU

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: concerning crates, pip packages etc

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
Allows us to remove some very dreaded `unsafe` code \o/

Went on a rabbit-hole trip to use the fancy new `map_buffer_on_submit` methods. But it's actually really hard to do so because by design, our read/write belts can use a single chunk (==buffer) on multiple command encoders. Therefore, it's really hard to know which command encoder is the one that you call `map_buffer_on_submit` on.
I noted down my learnings in the code comments, hopefully that prevents future generations to get confused by this.


Testing
* [x] Windows native
* [ ] Linux native
* [x] Mac native
* [x] WebGL
* [x] WebGPU

### Related

* closes https://linear.app/rerun/issue/RR-2340/order-partitions-by-the-opening-order

### What

This PR changes `StoreBundle` to use an `indexmap` instead of a `HashMap`, such that all iterator are sorted by insertion order. The main benefit is that recordings (and, in particular, partitions) are now ordered by opening order in the recording panel.

* Fixes RR-2481

### What

Going forward we want tranform queries to exist outside of the viewer, so questions like "what is the spatial relationship between a and b" can be answered programmatically. This PR takes the first step by moving all the pieces out and making them independent of the Viewer's environment.

`TransformTree` needed a little bit of decoupling, but otherwise this was quite straight forward!
We still have strong dependencies to re_query and EntityDb in general which are a bit harder to avoid since we're relying heavily on the there encoded query logic. But it's a much better starting point and gives us good initial constraints going forward.

@ reviewer: `crates/store/re_tf/src/transform_tree.rs` is a rename from `crates/viewer/re_view_spatial/src/contexts/transform_tree_context.rs`, I merely adjusted some function signature to unpack some viewer exclusive constructs (see the remaining/new `transform_tree_context` to learn what is necessary to do so)

### What

title: Make time and timeline controlled by blueprint

labels.name: sdk-python
labels.description: Python logging API

labels.name: 📺 re_viewer
labels.description: affects re_viewer itself

labels.name: 🟦 blueprint
labels.description: The data that defines our UI

body:
### Related

* Closes #7728

### What

Makes time cursor and current timeline be controlled by the blueprint.

### Details

We log the time as static for blueprints for it not to affect undo state.

This includes some refactors that felt necessary to make tests still work and not be overly complicated:
- `TestContext` doesn't require a mutable reference to run.
- Can update `TestContext` blueprints via `TestContext::with_blueprint_ctx`.
- The blueprint ctx is a struct that implements a helper trait for interacting with blueprints. App also has an equivalent `AppBlueprintCtx`, and `ViewerContext` also implements this trait.
- `TimeControl` is no longer stored behind an `RwLock` in app, and instead interacted with through sending `SystemCommand::TimeControlCommands`.

The time panel was refactored a bit to allow the normal time panel and blueprint inspector time panel to still share code. This is mostly changing `&mut TimeControl` to `&mut impl TimeControlCtx` which handles writing to blueprints/just updating time control whether this is the blueprint inspector time panel or not.

### TODO
 - [x] Fix times per timeline with blueprint stored time, probably not store time per timeline in blueprint now and instead "switch out" what time to use.
 - [x] Fix snapshot tests, the current produced results are most likely wrong.

title: Add meaningful equality comparisons to many rust wrappers

labels.name: sdk-python
labels.description: Python logging API

labels.name: 😤 annoying
labels.description: Something in the UI / SDK is annoying to use

body:
### What
pyo3 defaults `__eq__` to be equivalent to `is` but since we clone before returning most python objects that means
`dataset.schema()==dataset.schema()` is False even though the contents are identical.

I resolved this specific case and added a test.
Then I asked a robot to write me a lint to enforce this everywhere, updated for things I could easily `derive(PartialEq, Eq)` then added NOLINT to the rest.
The score is
| With eq | Without eq |
|---------|------------|
|      8       |      15           |

title: table provider: propagate stream error from IO loop

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

body:
### What

Right now if there's an error in the chunk fetching stream, it will be silently ignored. Instead here we make a change to propagate results from the IO loop and handle them in the CPU loop as we already handle errors in CPU loop. This ensures that receiving an error will actually result in stream termination (with an error).  

### Testing done
I didn't find a simple way to do this via a unit test since we can't really easily corrupt the OSS server. On the backend side I wrote pretty much exact test, but there I was able to simply change the ``FetchChunks`` request to ask for bogus data. 

Testing via benchmark:
```

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/zeljkomihaljcic/workspace/backup/dataplatform/services/component-tests/src/redap_tests/runner.py", line 214, in run_all
    metrics = test_func()
              ^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/zeljkomihaljcic/workspace/backup/dataplatform/services/component-tests/src/redap_tests/tests/droid.py", line 172, in sample_index_values
    (wrist.filter_index_values(sampled_times).fill_latest_at()).df().drop("rerun_partition_id").collect()
  File "/Users/zeljkomihaljcic/workspace/backup/dataplatform/.pixi/envs/examples/lib/python3.12/site-packages/datafusion/dataframe.py", line 598, in collect
    return self.df.collect()
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Exception: DataFusion error: Execution("Execution error: Failed streaming partition chunks\nDetails:gRPC error, code: 'Internal error', message: \"Internal(crates/redap_chunk_scanner/src/grpc/chunk_scanner.rs:203:17): failed fetching chunks: status: Internal, message: \\\"Mapper error: ObjectStore(crates/redap_partition_mappers/src/rrd_mapper.rs:250:27) <- Generic S3 error: Error performing HEAD https://s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/rerun-redap-datasets-eu-central-1/droid.2025.07.15/ILIAD/Sat_Sep__2_00%3A10%3A26_2023.rrd in 1.188433058s - Received redirect without LOCATION, this normally indicates an incorrectly configured region\\\", details: [], metadata: MetadataMap { headers: {} }\"")
```

title: Introduce `Lens` as a concept for semantic mapping of arbitrary data

labels.name: 🪵 Log & send APIs
labels.description: Affects the user-facing API for all languages

body:
### Related

* [x] Requires #11383.
* [x] Requires #11456.
* [x] Requires #11454.

### What

This PR introduces the concept of _Lenses_ as a way to express re-interpretation and manipulation of component columns. This can, for example, be useful to attach Rerun semantics to arbitrary Arrow components that are created when loading MCAP files.

For now, the only way to access the feature is via the `LensesSink`, which transforms component columns and then forwards aggregated chunks to the backing sink.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> Lenses are still a very experimental feature and we expect the API to change a lot in upcoming releases.
